aac.title: AAC audio file format
aac.description: Advanced Audio Coding format, designed to be the successor format to MP3, with generally better sound quality.
aac.notes: Support refers to this format's use in the `audio` element, not other conditions.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to only supporting AAC in an MP4 container and only when the operating system already has the codecs installed.

abortcontroller.title: AbortController & AbortSignal
abortcontroller.description: Controller object that allows you to abort one or more DOM requests made with the Fetch API.

notes_by_num.1: Safari has window.AbortController defined in the DOM but it's just a stub, it does not abort requests at all. The same issue also affects Chrome on IOS and Firefox on IOS because they use the same WebKit rendering engine as Safari.

accelerometer.title: Accelerometer
accelerometer.description: Defines `Accelerometer`, `LinearAccelerationSensor` and `GravitySensor` interfaces for obtaining information about acceleration applied to the X, Y and Z axis of a device that hosts the sensor.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor" experimental flag in `about:flags`

addeventlistener.title: EventTarget.addEventListener()
addeventlistener.description: The modern standard API for adding DOM event handlers. Introduced in the DOM Level 2 Events spec. Also implies support for `removeEventListener`, the [capture phase](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-event-capturing_phase) of DOM event dispatch, as well as the `stopPropagation()` and `preventDefault()` event methods.

notes_by_num.1: IE<=8 instead only supports the [proprietary `.attachEvent()` method](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener). It also does not support the [capture phase](https://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#event-flow) of DOM event dispatch; it only supports event bubbling.
notes_by_num.2: The `useCapture` parameter is non-optional and must be provided. Future versions made it optional, with a default value of `false`.

ambient-light.title: Ambient Light Sensor
ambient-light.description: Defines a concrete sensor interface to monitor the ambient light level or illuminance of the device’s environment.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Ambient Light Sensor
MDN Web Docs - Ambient Light Events

notes_by_num.1: Implements an [outdated version of the spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-ambient-light-20150903/).
notes_by_num.2: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor Extra Classes" experimental flag in `about:flags`

apng.title: Animated PNG (APNG)
apng.description: Like animated GIFs, but allowing 24-bit colors and alpha transparency

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice (under review)

apng.notes: Where support for APNG is missing, only the first frame is displayed

array-find.title: Array.prototype.find
array-find.description: The `find()` method returns the value of the first item in the array based on the result of the provided testing function.

links.title: Polyfill for this feature is available in the core-js library

array-find-index.title: Array.prototype.findIndex
array-find-index.description: The `findIndex()` method returns the index of the first element in the array that satisfies the provided testing function.

links.title: Polyfill for this feature is available in the core-js library

array-flat.title: flat & flatMap array methods
array-flat.description: Methods to flatten any sub-arrays found in an array by concatenating their elements.

links.title: Article on the history of the `flat` methods
Polyfill for this feature is available in the core-js library

array-includes.title: Array.prototype.includes
array-includes.description: Determines whether or not an array includes the given value, returning a boolean value (unlike `indexOf`).

links.title: Polyfill for this feature is available in the core-js library

arrow-functions.title: Arrow functions
arrow-functions.description: Function shorthand using `=>` syntax and lexical `this` binding.

asmjs.title: asm.js
asmjs.description: An extraordinarily optimizable, low-level subset of JavaScript, intended to be a compile target from languages like C++.

links.title: Bringing Asm.js to Chakra and Microsoft Edge

notes_by_num.1: Chrome does not support Ahead-Of-Time compilation but performance doubled in Chrome 28: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asm.js#Implementations
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable experimental JavaScript features" flag.

async-clipboard.title: Asynchronous Clipboard API
async-clipboard.description: A modern, asynchronous Clipboard API based on Promises

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to only supporting the "clipboard-write" permission and the "writeText" method.
notes_by_num.2: Supports writing to clipboard but not reading.

async-functions.title: Async functions
async-functions.description: Async functions make it possible to treat functions returning Promise objects as if they were synchronous.

notes_by_num.1: Since build 14342 - disabled by default; can be enabled through about:flags
notes_by_num.2: Async functions are present in Firefox Nightly since 31th October 2016.
notes_by_num.3: Async arrow functions are [unsupported](https://github.com/kangax/compat-table/pull/1420).

atob-btoa.title: Base64 encoding and decoding
atob-btoa.description: Utility functions for of encoding and decoding strings to and from base 64: window.atob() and window.btoa().

audio.title: Audio element
audio.description: Method of playing sound on webpages (without requiring a plug-in). Includes support for the following media properties: `currentSrc`, `currentTime`, `paused`, `playbackRate`, `buffered`, `duration`, `played`, `seekable`, `ended`, `autoplay`, `loop`, `controls`, `volume` & `muted`

links.title: Demos of audio player that uses the audio element

notes_by_num.1: Old Firefox versions were missing support for some properties: `loop` was added in v11, `played` in v15, `playbackRate` in v20.

audio-api.title: Web Audio API
audio-api.description: High-level JavaScript API for processing and synthesizing audio

links.title: Polyfill to support Web Audio API in Firefox
Additional browser compatibility tests for specific features
Polyfill to enable Web Audio API through Firefox Audio Data api or flash
MDN Web Docs - Web Audio API

audio-api.notes:
Not all browsers with support for the Audio API also support media streams (e.g. microphone input). See the [getUserMedia/Streams API](/#feat=stream) data for support for that feature.

Firefox versions < 25 support an alternative, deprecated audio API.

Chrome support [went through some changes](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2014/07/Web-Audio-Changes-in-m36) as of version 36.

audiotracks.title: Audio Tracks
audiotracks.description: Method of specifying and selecting between multiple audio tracks. Useful for providing audio descriptions, director's commentary, additional languages, alternative takes, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox by enabling "media.track.enabled" in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Chrome and Opera by enabling "enable-experimental-web-platform-features" in chrome:flags

autofocus.title: Autofocus attribute
autofocus.description: Allows a form field to be immediately focused on page load.
autofocus.notes: While not supported in iOS Safari, it does work in iOS WebViews.

auxclick.title: Auxclick
auxclick.description: The click event for non-primary buttons of input devices

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

auxclick.notes: With introduction of this feature there will be no longer click event fired for non-primary buttons

notes_by_num.1: As a compatibility measure, Firefox continues to fire the click event for document and window level event handlers.

av1.title: AV1 video format
av1.description: AV1 (AOMedia Video 1) is a royalty-free video format by the Alliance for Open Media, meant to succeed its predecessor VP9 and compete with the HEVC/H.265 format.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Edge 18 by installing the AV1 Video Extension from the Microsoft Store
notes_by_num.2: Firefox 65 only supported AV1 on Windows 64-bit
notes_by_num.3: Firefox 66 only supported AV1 on Windows and macOS
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in Firefox for Android via the `media.av1.enabled` flag in `about:config`

avif.title: AVIF image format
avif.description: A modern image format based on the AV1 video format. AVIF generally has better compression than [WebP](/webp), JPEG, PNG and GIF and is designed to supersede them. AVIF competes with [JPEG XL](/jpegxl) which has similar compression quality and is generally seen as more feature-rich than AVIF.

links.title: AVIF for Next-Generation Image Coding - blog post
Firefox support bug for image sequence and animation

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox via the `image.avif.enabled` pref in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.2: Only supports still images. AVIF sequences are not supported!

background-attachment.title: CSS background-attachment
background-attachment.description: Method of defining how a background image is attached to a scrollable element. Values include `scroll` (default), `fixed` and `local`.
background-attachment.notes: Most mobile devices have a delay in updating the background position after scrolling a page with `fixed` backgrounds.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting `fixed` but not `local`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting `local` but not `fixed`
notes_by_num.3: Only supports `local` when `-webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch` is _not_ used
notes_by_num.4: Does not support `fixed`, and due [to a bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=627037) only supports `local` if a `border-radius` is set on the element.
notes_by_num.5: Broken support of `fixed` and `local` when scrolling an outer scroll container. Related [to a bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=219324).

background-clip-text.title: Background-clip: text
background-clip-text.description: Non-standard method of clipping a background image to the foreground text.

links.title: CSS Backgrounds and Borders Module Level 4

background-clip-text.notes: Firefox and legacy Edge also support this property with the `-webkit-` prefix.

background-img-opts.title: CSS3 Background-image options
background-img-opts.description: New properties to affect background images, including background-clip, background-origin and background-size
background-img-opts.notes: Firefox, Chrome and Safari support the unofficial `-webkit-background-clip: text` (only with prefix). Safari does not support `-webkit-background-clip: text;` for `<button>` elements. But you can put `<span>` inside `<button>` to get the same result.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera Mini refers to not supporting background sizing or background attachments. However Opera Mini 7.5 supports background sizing (including cover and contain values).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 6 refers to not supporting background sizing offset from edges syntax.
notes_by_num.3: Does not support `background-size` values in the `background` shorthand

background-position-x-y.title: background-position-x & background-position-y
background-position-x-y.description: CSS longhand properties to define x or y positions separately.

links.title: Blog post on background-position-x & y properties

background-position-x-y.notes: A workaround for the lack of support in Firefox 31 - Firefox 48 is to use [CSS variables](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Using_CSS_variables). See [this Stack Overflow answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/29282573/94197) for an example.

background-repeat-round-space.title: CSS background-repeat round and space
background-repeat-round-space.description: Allows CSS background images to be repeated without clipping.

notes_by_num.1: IE9 does not appear to render "background-repeat: round" correctly.

background-sync.title: Background Sync API
background-sync.description: Provides one-off and periodic synchronization for Service Workers with an onsync event.

links.title: Google Developers blog: Introducing Background Sync

battery-status.title: Battery Status API
battery-status.description: Method to provide information about the battery status of the hosting device.
battery-status.notes: Firefox 52+ [removed access to this API due to privacy concerns.](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1313580)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support for the older specification's `navigator.battery` rather than `navigator.getBattery()` to access the `BatteryManager`.

beacon.title: Beacon API
beacon.description: Allows data to be sent asynchronously to a server with `navigator.sendBeacon`, even after a page was closed. Useful for posting analytics data the moment a user was finished using the page.

beforeafterprint.title: Printing Events
beforeafterprint.description: Window fires `beforeprint` and `afterprint` events so the printed document can be annotated.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Detecting print requests

beforeafterprint.notes: Due to its wider support, consider using `window.matchMedia('print')` where possible.

links.title: Blog article from Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled by setting `javascript.options.bigint` to "True" in `about:config`

blobbuilder.title: Blob constructing
blobbuilder.description: Construct Blobs (binary large objects) either using the BlobBuilder API (deprecated) or the Blob constructor.
blobbuilder.notes: Partial support refers to only supporting the now deprecated BlobBuilder to create blobs.

bloburls.title: Blob URLs
bloburls.description: Method of creating URL handles to the specified File or Blob object.

notes_by_num.1: Created blob url can't be used as object or iframe src

border-image.title: CSS3 Border images
border-image.description: Method of using images for borders
border-image.notes: Note that both the `border-style` and `border-width` must be specified (not set to `none` or 0) for border-images to work.

notes_by_num.1: Has a bug where `border-image` incorrectly overrides `border-style`. See [test case](https://codepen.io/Savago/pen/yYrgyK), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=99922), [discussion](https://github.com/whatwg/compat/issues/17)
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `border-image-repeat: space`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to supporting the shorthand syntax, but not the individual properties (`border-image-source`, `border-image-slice`, etc).
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to not supporting `border-image-repeat: round`

border-radius.title: CSS3 Border-radius (rounded corners)
border-radius.description: Method of making the border corners round. Covers support for the shorthand `border-radius` as well as the long-hand properties (e.g. `border-top-left-radius`)

notes_by_num.1: Safari 6.1 and earlier did not apply `border-radius` correctly to image borders: https://stackoverflow.com/q/17202128
notes_by_num.2: Dotted and dashed rounded border corners are rendered as solid in Firefox. [see bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=382721)

broadcastchannel.title: BroadcastChannel
broadcastchannel.description: BroadcastChannel allows scripts from the same origin but other browsing contexts (windows, workers) to send each other messages.

links.title: Shim - Broadcast Channel based on Localstorage, Indexeddb or Sockets

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

brotli.title: Brotli Accept-Encoding/Content-Encoding
brotli.description: More effective lossless compression algorithm than gzip and deflate.

links.title: WebKit Bug 154859: Add support for format brotli for HTTP compression

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Brotli Content-Encoding' flag
notes_by_num.2: Enabled since 27 May 2016
notes_by_num.3: Support starting with macOS 10.13 High Sierra

calc.title: calc() as CSS unit value
calc.description: Method of allowing calculated values for length units, i.e. `width: calc(100% - 3em)`
calc.notes:
Support can be somewhat emulated in older versions of IE using the non-standard `expression()` syntax.

Due to the way browsers handle [sub-pixel rounding](https://johnresig.com/blog/sub-pixel-problems-in-css/) differently, layouts using `calc()` expressions may have unexpected results.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android Browser 4.4 refers to the browser lacking the ability to multiply and divide values.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE9 refers to the browser crashing when used as a `background-position` value.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in IE10/IE11 refers to calc not working properly with various use cases mentioned in known issues

canvas.title: Canvas (basic support)
canvas.description: Method of generating fast, dynamic graphics using JavaScript.
canvas.notes:
For screen readers, IE, Chrome & Firefox support the [accessible canvas element sub-DOM](http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/2012/06/html5-canvas-accessibility-in-firefox-13/).
Firefox & Chrome also support the drawfocus ring.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `toDataURL()`
notes_by_num.2: Opera Mini supports the canvas element, but is unable to play animations or run other more complex applications.

canvas-blending.title: Canvas blend modes
canvas-blending.description: Method of defining the effect resulting from overlaying two layers on a Canvas element.

canvas-text.title: Text API for Canvas
canvas-text.description: Method of displaying text on Canvas elements

ch-unit.title: ch (character) unit
ch-unit.description: Unit representing the width of the character "0" in the current font, of particular use in combination with monospace fonts.

links.title: Blog post on using ch units
Various uses for the ch unit

notes_by_num.1: IE supports the `ch` unit, but unlike other browsers its width is that specifically of the "0" glyph, not its surrounding space. As a result, 3ch for example is shorter than the width of the string "000" in IE.

chacha20-poly1305.title: ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites for TLS
chacha20-poly1305.description: A set of cipher suites used in Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol, using ChaCha20 for symmetric encryption and Poly1305 for authentication.

links.title: SSL/TLS Capabilities of Your Browser by Qualys SSL Labs
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Old versions of Chrome use non-standard code points for ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites.

channel-messaging.title: Channel messaging
channel-messaging.description: Method for having two-way communication between browsing contexts (using MessageChannel)

links.title: An Introduction to HTML5 web messaging
MDN Web Docs - Channel Messaging API

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.messageChannel.enabled` flag. Reported to not work in web workers before version 41.

childnode-remove.title: ChildNode.remove()
childnode-remove.description: DOM node method to remove the node itself from the document.

classlist.title: classList (DOMTokenList)
classlist.description: Method of easily manipulating classes on elements, using the `DOMTokenList` object.

notes_by_num.1: Does not have support for `classList` on SVG or MathML elements.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the second parameter for the `toggle` method
notes_by_num.3: Does not support multiple parameters for the `add()` & `remove()` methods
notes_by_num.4: Does not support assign to `classList` or the `replace()` method

client-hints-dpr-width-viewport.title: Client Hints: DPR, Width, Viewport-Width
client-hints-dpr-width-viewport.description: DPR, Width, and Viewport-Width hints enable proactive content negotiation between client and server, enabling automated delivery of optimized assets - e.g. auto-negotiating image DPR resolution.

links.title: Automating resource selection with Client Hints
Mozilla Bug 935216 - Implement Client-Hints HTTP header
WebKit Bug 145380 - Add Content-DPR header support
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

client-hints-dpr-width-viewport.keywords: client hints, client-hints, dpr, viewport, content-dpr

clipboard.title: Synchronous Clipboard API
clipboard.description: API to provide copy, cut and paste events as well as provide access to the OS clipboard.
clipboard.notes:
Internet Explorer will display a security prompt for access to the OS clipboard.

Chrome 42+, Opera 29+ and Firefox 41+ support clipboard reading/writing only when part of a user action (click, keydown, etc).

notes_by_num.1: Only supports `Text` and `URL` data types and uses [a non-standard method](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/ms535220%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) of interacting with the clipboard.
notes_by_num.2: Only fires `copy` event on a valid selection and only `cut` and `paste` in focused editable fields.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports OS clipboard reading/writing via shortcut keys, not through `document.execCommand()`.
notes_by_num.4: Only supports `paste` event (on focused editable field).
notes_by_num.6: Supports `cut` & `copy` events without a focused editable field, but not `paste` (presumably for security reasons)
notes_by_num.7: Supports `cut` & `copy` events without a focused editable field, but does not fire `paste` with `document.execCommand('paste')`

colr.title: COLR/CPAL(v0) Font Formats
colr.description: The COLR table adds support for multi-colored glyphs in a manner that integrates with the rasterizers of existing text engines. COLRv0 only supports pure colors, does not support gradients, transformations and various blending modes.

links.title: Where can I use color fonts
A tool to check whether the browser supports OpenType color formats
Make COLR/CPAL format fonts in Glyphs app

notes_by_num.1: Supported only on Safari for macOS High Sierra (10.13)+
notes_by_num.2: Supported only on Windows 8.1+
notes_by_num.3: On Windows pre 8.1 and macOS Sierra (10.12) and below falls back to using FreeType: [Chromium bug 882844](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=882844#c3)

colr-v1.title: COLR/CPAL(v1) Font Formats
colr-v1.description: COLRv1 is an improved version of COLRv0, this is also part of the OpenType specification. COLRv1 supports additional graphic capabilities. In addition to solid colors, gradient fills can be used, as well as more complex fills using other graphic operations, including affine transformations and various blending modes.

links.title: COLRv1 Color Gradient Vector Fonts in Chrome 98
A tool to check whether the browser supports OpenType color formats
Where can I use color fonts

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled with the "COLR v1 Fonts" feature flag under `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.2: Firefox actively supports this format and will consider implementing it in the future: https://mozilla.github.io/standards-positions/#font-colrv1

comparedocumentposition.title: Node.compareDocumentPosition()
comparedocumentposition.description: Compares the relative position of two nodes to each other in the DOM tree.

notes_by_num.1: The spec requires that comparisons of nodes in different documents, and comparisons where at least one node is not in any document, must arbitrarily (but consistently) set either the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_PRECEDING` or `DOCUMENT_POSITION_FOLLOWING` bit in the result. These browser versions don't set either bit in some such cases.
notes_by_num.2: Sets neither the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_DISCONNECTED` bit nor the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_IMPLEMENTATION_SPECIFIC` bit in some cases when comparing nodes in different documents or when comparing a node which is not in any document.

console-basic.title: Basic console logging functions
console-basic.description: Method of outputting data to the browser's console, intended for development purposes.
console-basic.notes: The basic functions that this information refers to include `console.log`, `console.info`, `console.warn`, `console.error`.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports console functions when developer tools are open, otherwise the `console` object is undefined and any calls will throw errors.
notes_by_num.2: Allows `console` functions to be used without throwing errors, but does not appear to output the data anywhere.
notes_by_num.3: Log output on iOS 6+ Safari can only be seen by connecting to a Mac and using the [Safari debugger](https://developer.apple.com/safari/tools/).
notes_by_num.4: Log output on older Android browsers can be retrieved via Android's `logcat` command or using Chrome Developer Tools in Android 4.4+/Chrome for Android [see details](https://developer.android.com/guide/webapps/debugging.html)
notes_by_num.5: Log output on Firefox for Android can be [accessed using WebIDE](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Tools/Remote_Debugging/Debugging_Firefox_for_Android_with_WebIDE)
notes_by_num.6: See [this article](https://dev.opera.com/articles/opera-mini-and-javascript/) for details on how to see console logging in Opera Mini

console-time.title: console.time and console.timeEnd
console-time.notes: `console.time()` starts a timer you can use to track how long an operation takes. You give each timer a unique name, and may have up to 10,000 timers running on a given page. When you call `console.timeEnd()` with the same name, the browser will output the time, in milliseconds, that elapsed since the timer was started. These functions are not always available in `workers`. For example, in Firefox, they are available from version `38`. More on using the `console` on mobile devices, see [here](https://caniuse.com/#feat=console-basic).

const.title: const
const.description: Declares a constant with block level scope

notes_by_num.1: const is recognized, but treated like var (no block scope, can be overwritten)
notes_by_num.2: const does not have block scope
notes_by_num.3: Only recognized when NOT in strict mode
notes_by_num.4: Supported correctly in strict mode, otherwise supported without block scope
notes_by_num.5: Not supported in for-in and for-of loops

constraint-validation.title: Constraint Validation API
constraint-validation.description: API for better control over form field validation. Includes support for `checkValidity()`, `setCustomValidity()`, `reportValidity()` and validation states.

links.title: MS Edge UserVoice request for reportValidity

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `reportValidity`
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `validity.tooShort`. See also [support for `minlength`.](https://caniuse.com/#feat=input-minlength)
notes_by_num.3: Does not support `validity.badInput`

contenteditable.title: contenteditable attribute (basic support)
contenteditable.description: Method of making any HTML element editable.
contenteditable.notes: This support only refers to very basic editing capability, implementations vary significantly on how certain elements can be edited.

contentsecuritypolicy.title: Content Security Policy 1.0
contentsecuritypolicy.description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by only allowing certain sources of script, style, and other resources.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Content Security Policy

contentsecuritypolicy.notes: The standard HTTP header is `Content-Security-Policy` which is used unless otherwise noted.

notes_by_num.1: Supported through the `X-Content-Security-Policy` header
notes_by_num.2: Supported through the `X-WebKit-CSP` header

contentsecuritypolicy2.title: Content Security Policy Level 2
contentsecuritypolicy2.description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by only allowing certain sources of script, style, and other resources. CSP 2 adds hash-source, nonce-source, and five new directives

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Content Security Policy

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 31-34 is missing the child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox 35 is missing the child-src, frame-ancestors, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox 36-44 is missing the child-src directives.
notes_by_num.4: Chrome 36-38 & Opera 23-25 are missing the child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.5: Chrome 39 and Opera 26 are missing the child-src, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.6: Edge has broken nonce support as it ignores nonces on sourced scripts.

cookie-store-api.title: Cookie Store API
cookie-store-api.description: An API for reading and modifying cookies. Compared to the existing `document.cookie` method, the API provides a much more modern interface, which can also be used in service workers.

links.title: Article on using the Cookie Store API

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled with the `#enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag.

cors.title: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing
cors.description: Method of performing XMLHttpRequests across domains

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Access control CORS

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CORS for images in `<canvas>`
notes_by_num.2: Supported somewhat in IE8 and IE9 using the XDomainRequest object (but has [limitations](https://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/05/13/xdomainrequest-restrictions-limitations-and-workarounds.aspx))
notes_by_num.3: Does not support CORS for `<video>` in `<canvas>`: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=135379
notes_by_num.4: Does not support CORS for resources which redirect: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1346749

createimagebitmap.title: createImageBitmap
createimagebitmap.description: Create image bitmap with support for resizing and adjusting quality

notes_by_num.1: No support for options parameter, resizeWidth, resizeHeight, resizeQuality or SVGImageElement as Source Image
notes_by_num.2: No support for resizeWidth, resizeHeight, resizeQuality or SVGImageElement as Source Image
notes_by_num.3: No support for SVGImageElement as Source Image
notes_by_num.4: No support for resizeWidth, resizeHeight and resizeQuality. See [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1363861)
notes_by_num.5: No support for `createImageBitmap(source, options)` interface. see [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1335594)

credential-management.title: Credential Management API
credential-management.description: API that provides a programmatic interface to the browser's credential manager. In short, an origin can request a user's credentials to sign them in, or can ask the browser to save credentials on the user's behalf. Both of these requests are user-mediated.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Credential Management API

notes_by_num.1: In Chrome 51 ~ 56, PSL matched credentials are not supported. This means you cannot use credentials set on a.example.com in b.example.com. This is supported since Chrome 57.

cryptography.title: Web Cryptography
cryptography.description: JavaScript API for performing basic cryptographic operations in web applications

links.title: The History and Status of Web Crypto API
Support for recommended algorithms in Firefox
Polyfill by Netflix with partial support
PKI.js - another crypto library for Public Key Infrastructure applications
Web Cryptography API shim for IE11 and Safari - set of bugfixes and workarounds of prefixed api implementations
MDN Web Docs - Web Crypto API

cryptography.notes: Many browsers support the `[crypto.getRandomValues()](#feat=getrandomvalues)` method, but not actual cryptography functionality under `crypto.subtle`.

notes_by_num.1: Support in IE11 is based on an older version of the specification.
notes_by_num.2: Support in Safari before version 11 was using the `crypto.webkitSubtle` prefix.
notes_by_num.3: In Edge 12-18, Web Crypto was not supported in Web Workers and Service Workers.

css-all.title: CSS all property
css-all.description: A shorthand property for resetting all CSS properties except for `direction` and `unicode-bidi`.

links.title: WebKit bug 116966: [css3-cascade] Add support for `all` shorthand property
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-animation.title: CSS Animation
css-animation.description: Complex method of animating certain properties of an element

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android browser refers to buggy behavior in different scenarios.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `steps()`, `step-start` & `step-end` timing functions

css-any-link.title: CSS :any-link selector
css-any-link.description: The `:any-link` CSS pseudo-class matches all elements that match `:link` or `:visited`

css-appearance.title: CSS Appearance
css-appearance.description: The `appearance` property defines how elements (particularly form controls) appear by default. By setting the value to `none` the default appearance can be entirely redefined using other CSS properties.
css-appearance.notes: WebKit, Blink, and Gecko browsers also support additional vendor specific values.

notes_by_num.1: The appearance property is supported with the `none` value, but not `auto`.
notes_by_num.2: Microsoft Edge and IE Mobile support this property with the `-webkit-` prefix, rather than `-ms-` for interop reasons.
notes_by_num.3: `-moz-appearance:none` did not remove the dropdown arrow in the select tag

css-at-counter-style.title: CSS Counter Styles
css-at-counter-style.description: The @counter-style CSS at-rule allows custom counter styles to be defined. A @counter-style rule defines how to convert a counter value into a string representation.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - CSS counter style

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking support for image symbols: [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1024179), [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1176323)

css-backdrop-filter.title: CSS Backdrop Filter
css-backdrop-filter.description: Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale or hue) to content/elements below the target element.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - CSS backdrop filter

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Currently only supported with the `-webkit-` prefix (not -ms-)
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled by setting the `layout.css.backdrop-filter.enabled` and `gfx.webrender.all` preference to `true` in about:config.

css-background-offsets.title: CSS background-position edge offsets
css-background-offsets.description: Allows CSS background images to be positioned relative to the specified edge using the 3 to 4 value syntax. For example: `background-position: right 5px bottom 5px;` for positioning 5px from the bottom-right corner.

css-backgroundblendmode.title: CSS background-blend-mode
css-backgroundblendmode.description: Allows blending between CSS background images, gradients, and colors.

notes_by_num.1: Partial in Safari refers to not supporting the `hue`, `saturation`, `color`, and `luminosity` blend modes.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome 46 has some [serious bugs](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=543583) with multiply, difference, and exclusion blend modes

css-boxdecorationbreak.title: CSS box-decoration-break
css-boxdecorationbreak.description: Controls whether the box's margins, borders, padding, and other decorations wrap the broken edges of the box fragments (when the box is split by a break (page/column/region/line).

links.title: Demo of effect on box border
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to working for inline elements but not across column or page breaks.

css-boxshadow.title: CSS3 Box-shadow
css-boxshadow.description: Method of displaying an inner or outer shadow effect to elements
css-boxshadow.notes: Can be partially emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "shadow" filter.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Safari, iOS Safari and Android Browser refers to missing "inset", blur radius value, and multiple shadow support.

css-canvas.title: CSS Canvas Drawings
css-canvas.description: Method of using HTML5 Canvas as a background image. Not currently part of any specification.
css-canvas.notes: A similar effect can be achieved in Firefox 4+ using the -moz-element() background property

css-caret-color.title: CSS caret-color
css-caret-color.description: The `caret-color` property allows the color to be set of the caret (blinking text insertion pointer) in an editable text area.

css-cascade-layers.title: CSS Cascade Layers
css-cascade-layers.description: The `@layer` at-rule allows authors to explicitly layer their styles in the cascade, before specificity and order of appearance are considered.

links.title: The Future of CSS: Cascade Layers (CSS @layer)

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled with the "layout.css.cascade-layers.enabled" feature flag under `about:config`
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Chrome Canary using the `--enable-blink-features=CSSCascadeLayers` runtime flag
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in the Experimental Features developer menu

css-case-insensitive.title: Case-insensitive CSS attribute selectors
css-case-insensitive.description: Including an `i` before the `]` in a CSS attribute selector causes the attribute value to be matched in an ASCII-case-insensitive manner. For example, `[b="xyz" i]` would match both `<a b="xyz">` and `<a b="XYZ">`.

links.title: MS Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-clip-path.title: CSS clip-path property (for HTML)
css-clip-path.description: Method of defining the visible region of an HTML element using SVG or a shape definition.

links.title: Codepen Example Clipping an Image with a Polygon
Chromium bug for shapes in external SVGs
WebKit bug for shapes in external SVGs

css-clip-path.notes: Support refers to the `clip-path` CSS property on HTML elements specifically. Support for `clip-path` in SVG is supported in all browsers with [basic SVG](#feat=svg) support.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting the `url()` syntax.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting shapes and the `url(#foo)` syntax for inline SVG, but not shapes in external SVGs.
notes_by_num.3: Supports shapes behind the `layout.css.clip-path-shapes.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.4: Partial support can be enabled on MS Edge with the Enable CSS Clip-Path Flag
notes_by_num.5: While Edge doesn't seem to recognize any `<basic-shape>` function, it does allow you to use `polygon()` in HTML and SVG

css-color-adjust.title: CSS color-adjust
css-color-adjust.description: The `color-adjust` (or `-webkit-print-color-adjust` as prefixed in WebKit/Blink browsers) property is a CSS extension that can be used to force printing of background colors and images.

css-color-function.title: CSS color() function
css-color-function.description: The CSS `color()` function allows the browser to display colors in any color space, such as the P3 color space which can display colors outside of the default sRGB color space.

links.title: WebKit article on using color() with the P3 color space
Color generator that uses color() with the P3 color space

css-color-function.notes: For this function to work properly, the device screen and OS also needs to support the color space being used.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports `display-p3` predefined color profile.

css-conic-gradients.title: CSS Conical Gradients
css-conic-gradients.description: Method of defining a conical or repeating conical color gradient as a CSS image.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
Mozilla bug #1175958: Implement conic gradients from CSS Image Values Level 4

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Does not support multi-position color stops
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled with the `layout.css.conic-gradient.enabled` flag

css-container-queries.title: CSS Container Queries
css-container-queries.description: Experimental media query to apply styles based on specified container elements rather than the entire page. Currently implemented using the `container` properties and `@container` at-rule.

links.title: Container Queries: a Quick Start Guide

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled with the "Enable CSS Container Queries" feature flag under `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.2: The initial Chrome prototype used an earlier draft syntax based on the `contain` property

css-containment.title: CSS Containment
css-containment.description: The CSS `contain` property lets developers limit the scope of the browser's styles, layout and paint work for faster and more efficient rendering.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in older Gecko engines with the `layout.css.contain.enabled` flag in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Partially supported in Firefox by enabling "layout.css.contain.enabled" in about:config
notes_by_num.3: Supported in Safari TP by enabling "CSS Containment" under the "Experimental Features" menu

css-content-visibility.title: CSS content-visibility
css-content-visibility.description: Provides control over when elements are rendered, so rendering can be skipped for elements not yet in the user's viewport.

links.title: content-visibility: the new CSS property that boosts your rendering performance

css-counters.title: CSS Counters
css-counters.description: Method of controlling number values in generated content, using the `counter-reset` and `counter-increment` properties.

css-crisp-edges.title: Crisp edges/pixelated images
css-crisp-edges.description: Scales images with an algorithm that preserves edges and contrast, without smoothing colors or introducing blur. This is intended for images such as pixel art. Official values that accomplish this for the `image-rendering` property are `crisp-edges` and `pixelated`.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - CSS Image rendering

css-crisp-edges.notes: Note that prefixes apply to the value (e.g. `-moz-crisp-edges`), not the `image-rendering` property.

notes_by_num.1: Supported using the non-standard value `-webkit-optimize-contrast`
notes_by_num.2: Internet Explorer accomplishes support using the non-standard declaration `-ms-interpolation-mode: nearest-neighbor`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the `crisp-edges` value, but not `pixelated`.
notes_by_num.4: Supports the `pixelated` value, but not `crisp-edges`.
notes_by_num.5: Only works on ``, not CSS backgrounds or ``.
notes_by_num.6: Only works on `` and CSS backgrounds, _not_ ``.

css-cross-fade.title: CSS Cross-Fade Function
css-cross-fade.description: Image function to create a "crossfade" between images. This allows one image to transition (fade) into another based on a percentage value.

css-default-pseudo.title: :default CSS pseudo-class
css-default-pseudo.description: The `:default` pseudo-class matches checkboxes and radio buttons which are checked by default, `<option>`s with the `selected` attribute, and the default submit button (if any) of a form.

links.title: MS Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug 156230 - `:default` CSS pseudo-class should match checkboxes+radios with a `checked` attribute

css-default-pseudo.notes: Whether `<option selected>` matches `:default` (per the spec) was not tested since `<select>`s and `<option>`s are generally not styleable, which makes it hard to formulate a test for this.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match `<input type="checkbox" checked>` or `<input type="radio" checked>`
notes_by_num.2: Does not match the default submit button of a form

css-descendant-gtgt.title: Explicit descendant combinator >>
css-descendant-gtgt.description: An explicit, non-whitespace spelling of the descendant combinator. `A >> B` is equivalent to `A B`.

links.title: Mozilla bug #1266283 - Implement CSS4 descendant combinator `>>`

css-deviceadaptation.title: CSS Device Adaptation
css-deviceadaptation.description: Method of overriding the size of viewport in web page using the `@viewport` rule, replacing Apple's own popular `<meta>` viewport implementation. Includes the `extend-to-zoom` width value.

links.title: Introduction to meta viewport and @viewport in Opera Mobile

css-deviceadaptation.notes: Due to lack of implementation this specification [is slated to be retired](https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/4766).

notes_by_num.1: IE only supports the 'width' and 'height' properties.
notes_by_num.2: Opera Mobile and Opera Mini only support the 'orientation' property.

css-dir-pseudo.title: :dir() CSS pseudo-class
css-dir-pseudo.description: Matches elements based on their directionality. `:dir(ltr)` matches elements which are Left-to-Right. `:dir(rtl)` matches elements which are Right-to-Left.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug #64861: Need support for :dir() pseudo-class

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `#enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag

css-display-contents.title: CSS display: contents
css-display-contents.description: `display: contents` causes an element's children to appear as if they were direct children of the element's parent, ignoring the element itself. This can be useful when a wrapper element should be ignored when using CSS grid or similar layout techniques.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to [severe implementation bug](https://hiddedevries.nl/en/blog/2018-04-21-more-accessible-markup-with-display-contents) that renders the content inaccessible.
notes_by_num.3: Safari support is buggy, see [WebKit bug 188259](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=188259) & [WebKit bug 193567](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=193567)

css-element-function.title: CSS element() function
css-element-function.description: This function renders a live image generated from an arbitrary HTML element

notes_by_num.1: In Firefox < 4, usage limited to the background and background-image CSS properties

links.title: The env() CSS Function - MDN Web Docs
Designing Websites for iPhone X - WebKit Blog

notes_by_num.1: Supported as `constant()` instead of `env()`

css-exclusions.title: CSS Exclusions Level 1
css-exclusions.description: Exclusions defines how inline content flows around elements. It extends the content wrapping ability of floats to any block-level element.

css-featurequeries.title: CSS Feature Queries
css-featurequeries.description: CSS Feature Queries allow authors to condition rules based on whether particular property declarations are supported in CSS using the @supports at rule.

css-filter-function.title: CSS filter() function
css-filter-function.description: This function filters a CSS input image with a set of filter functions (like blur, grayscale or hue)

css-filters.title: CSS Filter Effects
css-filters.description: Method of applying filter effects using the `filter` property to elements, matching filters available in SVG. Filter functions include blur, brightness, contrast, drop-shadow, grayscale, hue-rotate, invert, opacity, sepia and saturate.
css-filters.notes: Note that this property is significantly different from and incompatible with Microsoft's [older "filter" property](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/ms530752%28v=vs.85%29.aspx).

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.filters.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable CSS filter property" flag.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox before version 34 [only implemented the url() function of the filter property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/filter#Browser_compatibility)
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to supporting filter functions, but not the `url` function.

css-first-letter.title: ::first-letter CSS pseudo-element selector
css-first-letter.description: CSS pseudo-element that allows styling only the first "letter" of text within an element. Useful for implementing initial caps or drop caps styling.
css-first-letter.notes: The spec says that both letters of digraphs which are always capitalized together (such as "IJ" in Dutch) should be matched by ::first-letter, but no browser has ever implemented this.

notes_by_num.1: Excludes punctuation immediately after the first letter from the match. (The spec says it should be included in the match.)
notes_by_num.2: Acts like the first character is always a letter even when it's not. For example, given "!,X;", "!," is matched instead of the entire string.
notes_by_num.3: Only recognizes the deprecated :first-letter pseudo-class, not the ::first-letter pseudo-element.
notes_by_num.4: Only matches the very first character. The spec says that surrounding punctuation should also match.

css-first-line.title: CSS first-line pseudo-element
css-first-line.description: Allows styling specifically for the first line of text using the `::first-line` pseudo-element. Note that only a limited set of properties can be applied.

notes_by_num.1: IE8 only supports the single-colon CSS 2.1 syntax (i.e. `:first-line`). It does not support the double-colon CSS3 syntax (i.e. `::first-line`).

css-fixed.title: CSS position:fixed
css-fixed.description: Method of keeping an element in a fixed location regardless of scroll position

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older iOS Safari refers to [buggy behavior](http://remysharp.com/2012/05/24/issues-with-position-fixed-scrolling-on-ios/).
notes_by_num.2: Only works in Android 2.1 thru 2.3 by using the following meta tag: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, user-scalable=no">.
notes_by_num.3: Android 4.0-4.3 [ignore transforms and margin:auto on position:fixed elements](https://codepen.io/mattiacci/pen/mPRKZY).
notes_by_num.4: in Safari 9.1, having a `position:fixed`-element inside an animated element, [may cause the `position:fixed`-element to not appear](https://jsbin.com/fuxipax).

css-focus-visible.title: :focus-visible CSS pseudo-class
css-focus-visible.description: The `:focus-visible` pseudo-class applies while an element matches the `:focus` pseudo-class, and the UA determines via heuristics that the focus should be specially indicated on the element (typically via a “focus ring”).

links.title: Chrome does not support CSS Selectors 4 :focus-visible
Blink: Intent to implement :focus-visible pseudo class.
WebKit bug #185859: [selectors] Support for Focus-Indicated Pseudo-class: `:focus-visible`

notes_by_num.1: As `:-moz-focusring`
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled via ":focus-visible pseudo-class" in the Experimental Features menu

css-focus-within.title: :focus-within CSS pseudo-class
css-focus-within.description: The `:focus-within` pseudo-class matches elements that either themselves match `:focus` or that have descendants which match `:focus`.

links.title: The Future Generation of CSS Selectors: Level 4: Generalized Input Focus Pseudo-class
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug #140144: Add support for CSS4 `:focus-within` pseudo
Chromium issue #617371: Implement `:focus-within` pseudo-class from Selectors Level 4
Mozilla bug #1176997: Add support for pseudo class `:focus-within`

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

css-font-palette.title: CSS font-palette
css-font-palette.description: The font-palette CSS property allows selecting a palette from a color font. In combination with the `@font-palette-values` at-rule, custom palettes can be defined.

css-font-rendering-controls.title: CSS font-display
css-font-rendering-controls.description: `@font-face` descriptor `font-display` that allows control over how a downloadable font renders before it is fully loaded.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `layout.css.font-display.enabled` flag

css-font-stretch.title: CSS font-stretch
css-font-stretch.description: If a font has multiple types of variations based on the width of characters, the `font-stretch` property allows the appropriate one to be selected. The property in itself does not cause the browser to stretch to a font.

css-gencontent.title: CSS Generated content for pseudo-elements
css-gencontent.description: Method of displaying text or images before or after the given element's contents using the ::before and ::after pseudo-elements. All browsers with support also support the `attr()` notation in the `content` property.
css-gencontent.notes: For content to appear in pseudo-elements, the `content` property must be set (but may be an empty string).

notes_by_num.1: IE8 only supports the single-colon CSS 2.1 syntax (i.e. :pseudo-class). It does not support the double-colon CSS3 syntax (i.e. ::pseudo-element).

css-gradients.title: CSS Gradients
css-gradients.description: Method of defining a linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.

links.title: Tool to emulate support in IE

css-gradients.notes:
Syntax used by browsers with prefixed support may be incompatible with that for proper support.

Support can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "gradient" filter. 

Firefox 10+, Opera 11.6+, Chrome 26+ and IE10+ also support the new "to (side)" syntax.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera 11.10 and 11.50 also refers to only having support for linear gradients.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari and Older Firefox versions refers to not using premultiplied colors which results in unexpected behavior when using the transparent keyword as advised by the [spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/CR-css3-images-20120417/#color-stop-syntax).
notes_by_num.3: Implements an earlier prefixed syntax as `-webkit-gradient`

css-grid.title: CSS Grid Layout (level 1)
css-grid.description: Method of using a grid concept to lay out content, providing a mechanism for authors to divide available space for layout into columns and rows using a set of predictable sizing behaviors. Includes support for all `grid-*` properties and the `fr` unit.

links.title: Css Grid By Example: Everything you need to learn CSS Grid Layout
Mozilla: Introduction to CSS Grid Layout

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to supporting an [older version](https://www.w3.org/TR/2011/WD-css3-grid-layout-20110407/) of the specification.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled in Firefox through the `layout.css.grid.enabled ` flag
notes_by_num.4: There are some bugs with overflow ([1356820](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1356820), [1348857](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1348857), [1350925](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1350925))

css-hanging-punctuation.title: CSS hanging-punctuation
css-hanging-punctuation.description: Allows some punctuation characters from start (or the end) of text elements to be placed "outside" of the box in order to preserve the reading flow.

css-has.title: :has() CSS relational pseudo-class
css-has.description: Only select elements containing specified content. For example, `a:has(>img)` selects all `` elements that contain an `` child.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the [Experimental Web Platform features](chrome://flags/#enable-experimental-web-platform-features) flag

css-hyphens.title: CSS Hyphenation
css-hyphens.description: Method of controlling when words at the end of lines should be hyphenated using the "hyphens" property.
css-hyphens.notes: Chrome < 55 and Android 4.0 Browser support "-webkit-hyphens: none", but not the "auto" property. It is [advisable to set the @lang attribute](http://blog.adrianroselli.com/2015/01/on-use-of-lang-attribute.html) on the HTML element to enable hyphenation support and improve accessibility.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported on Android & Mac platforms (and only the "auto" value) for now. [See commit](https://crrev.com/ed7e106e0e48b3afb160a5bdbb37649e307d2b05) & related [bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=652964).
notes_by_num.2: Only supported on Android & Mac platforms

css-image-orientation.title: CSS3 image-orientation
css-image-orientation.description: CSS property used generally to fix the intended orientation of an image. This can be done using 90 degree increments or based on the image's EXIF data using the "from-image" value.

links.title: Chromium bug #158753: Support for the CSS image-orientation CSS property

css-image-orientation.notes: Opening the image in a new tab in Chrome results in the image shown in the orientation according to the EXIF data.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in iOS refers to the browser using EXIF data by default, though it does not actually support the property.
notes_by_num.2: Has [a bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1082669) where the browser is not maintaining the image’s aspect ratio when `object-fit: cover` and `image-orientation: from-image` are used together.

css-image-set.title: CSS image-set
css-image-set.description: Method of letting the browser pick the most appropriate CSS image from a given set.

links.title: Chromium bug to update and unprefix image-set()

notes_by_num.1: Has very limited support. Only `url()` is accepted as the image and only `x` is accepted as a resolution.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support generated images in `content`. Example: `content: image-set(linear-gradient())`. [Bug 1696314](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1696314).
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `type()` function.

css-in-out-of-range.title: :in-range and :out-of-range CSS pseudo-classes
css-in-out-of-range.description: If a temporal or number `<input>` has `max` and/or `min` attributes, then `:in-range` matches when the value is within the specified range and `:out-of-range` matches when the value is outside the specified range. If there are no range constraints, then neither pseudo-class matches.
css-in-out-of-range.notes: Note that `<input type="range">` can never match `:out-of-range` because the user cannot input such a value, and if the initial value is outside the range, the browser immediately clamps it to the minimum or maximum (as appropriate) bound of the range.

notes_by_num.1: Opera Mini correctly applies style on initial load, but does not correctly update when value is changed.
notes_by_num.2: `:in-range` also incorrectly matches temporal and `number` inputs which don't have `min` or `max` attributes. See [Edge bug](https://web.archive.org/web/20171213080515/https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/7200501/), [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=603268), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156558).
notes_by_num.3: `:in-range` and `:out-of-range` incorrectly match inputs which are disabled or readonly. See [Edge bug](https://web.archive.org/web/20171213073431/https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/7190958/), [Mozilla bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1264157), [WebKit bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156530), [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=602568).

css-indeterminate-pseudo.title: :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class
css-indeterminate-pseudo.description: The `:indeterminate` pseudo-class matches indeterminate checkboxes, indeterminate `<progress>` bars, and radio buttons with no checked button in their radio button group.

links.title: EdgeHTML issue 7124038 - `:indeterminate` pseudo-class doesn't match radio buttons
Mozilla Bug 885359 - Radio groups without a selected radio button should have `:indeterminate` applying
WebKit Bug 156270 - `:indeterminate` pseudo-class should match radios whose group has no checked radio

notes_by_num.1: Doesn't match radio buttons whose radio button group lacks a checked radio button
notes_by_num.2: Doesn't support the `<progress>` element
notes_by_num.3: Doesn't match indeterminate `<progress>` bars

css-initial-letter.title: CSS Initial Letter
css-initial-letter.description: Method of creating an enlarged cap, including a drop or raised cap, in a robust way.

links.title: Blog post on Envato Tuts+, "Better CSS Drop Caps With initial-letter"

notes_by_num.1: Safari implementation is incomplete. Does not allow applying web fonts to the initial letter.

css-initial-value.title: CSS initial value
css-initial-value.description: A CSS value that will apply a property's initial value as defined in the CSS specification that defines the property

notes_by_num.1: Not supported on `quotes` property

css-lch-lab.title: LCH and Lab color values
css-lch-lab.description: The `lch()` and `lab()` color functions are based on the CIE LAB color space, representing colors in a way that closely matches human perception and provides access to a wider spectrum of colors than offered by the usual RGB color space.

links.title: LCH colors in CSS: what, why, and how?

css-letter-spacing.title: letter-spacing CSS property
css-letter-spacing.description: Controls spacing between characters of text (i.e. "tracking" in typographical terms). Not to be confused with kerning.

notes_by_num.1: Truncates or rounds fractional portions of values

css-line-clamp.title: CSS line-clamp
css-line-clamp.description: CSS property that will contain text to a given amount of lines when used in combination with `display: -webkit-box`. It will end with ellipsis when `text-overflow: ellipsis` is included.

links.title: Article on cross-browser CSS line clamping

css-line-clamp.notes: Older (presto-based) versions of the Opera browser have also supported the same effect using the proprietary `-o-ellipsis-lastline;` value for `text-overflow`.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in MS Edge with `-webkit-` prefix only (not with `-ms-`)

css-logical-props.title: CSS Logical Properties
css-logical-props.description: Logical properties and values provide control of layout through logical, rather than physical, direction and dimension mappings. These properties are `writing-mode` relative equivalents of their corresponding physical properties.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
MDN - Basic concepts of Logical Properties and Values

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the *-start, and *-end values for `margin`, `border` and `padding`, not the inline/block type values as defined in the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Like #1 but also supports `*-before` and `*-end` for `*-block-start` and `*-block-end` properties as well as `start` and `end` values for `text-align`
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `margin-block`, `margin-inline`, `padding-block`, `padding-inline`, or any of the `inset` shorthand properties. Supported in newer Chromium browsers behind the `#enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag
notes_by_num.4: Does not support the `border-start-start-radius`, `border-start-end-radius`, `border-end-start-radius` and `border-end-end-radius` property.
notes_by_num.5: Does not support the `border-start-start-radius`, `border-start-end-radius`, `border-end-start-radius` and `border-end-end-radius` property.

css-marker-pseudo.title: CSS ::marker pseudo-element
css-marker-pseudo.description: The `::marker` pseudo-element allows list item markers to be styled or have their content value customized.

notes_by_num.1: Safari supports [the definition in the CSS Pseudo-Elements Module Level 4](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-pseudo-4/#marker-pseudo) instead of one in the List module due to the flux definition in it.
notes_by_num.2: Safari support is limited to color and font-size. See bug [204163](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=204163).

css-masks.title: CSS Masks
css-masks.description: Method of displaying part of an element, using a selected image as a mask

links.title: Detailed blog post (via The Internet Archive)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in WebKit/Blink browsers refers to supporting the mask-image and mask-box-image properties, but lacking support for other parts of the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Firefox refers to only support for inline SVG mask elements i.e. mask: url(#foo).
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to supporting the mask-box-image shorthand but not the longhand properties
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in MS edge behind the "Enable CSS Masking" flag.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to supporting mask-image and mask-size
notes_by_num.6: Partial support refers to supporting mask-image, mask-size, mask-position, mask-repeat and mask-composite
notes_by_num.7: Edge also recognizes and supports all the `-webkit-` prefixed equivalents of the unprefixed properties for site compatibility

css-matches-pseudo.title: :is() CSS pseudo-class
css-matches-pseudo.description: The `:is()` (formerly `:matches()`, formerly `:any()`) pseudo-class checks whether the element at its position in the outer selector matches any of the selectors in its selector list. It's useful syntactic sugar that allows you to avoid writing out all the combinations manually as separate selectors. The effect is similar to nesting in Sass and most other CSS preprocessors.

links.title: WebKit blog post about adding `:matches()` and other Selectors Level 4 features

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the deprecated `:-webkit-any()` pseudo-class
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the deprecated `:-webkit-any()` and `:matches()` pseudo-classes
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the deprecated `:-moz-any()` pseudo-class.
notes_by_num.4: Support for `:is()` can be enabled with the `Experimental Web Platform features` flag

css-math-functions.title: CSS math functions min(), max() and clamp()
css-math-functions.description: More advanced mathematical expressions in addition to `calc()`

links.title: MDN Web Docs article for min()
MDN Web Docs article for max()
MDN Web Docs article for clamp()
Getting Started With CSS Math Functions Level 4

notes_by_num.1: Safari did not support `clamp()`

css-media-interaction.title: Media Queries: interaction media features
css-media-interaction.description: Allows a media query to be set based on the presence and accuracy of the user's pointing device, and whether they have the ability to hover over elements on the page. This includes the `pointer`, `any-pointer`, `hover`, and `any-hover` media features.

links.title: Potential use cases for script, hover and pointer CSS Level 4 Media Features
Interaction Media Features and their potential (for incorrect assumptions)

css-media-resolution.title: Media Queries: resolution feature
css-media-resolution.description: Allows a media query to be set based on the device pixels used per CSS unit. While the standard uses `min`/`max-resolution` for this, some browsers support the older non-standard `device-pixel-ratio` media query.

links.title: WebKit Bug 78087: Implement the 'resolution' media query

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `dpi` unit, but does not support `dppx` or `dpcm` units.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox before 16 supports only `dpi` unit, but you can set `2dppx` per `min--moz-device-pixel-ratio: 2`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the non-standard `min`/`max-device-pixel-ratio`

css-mediaqueries.title: CSS3 Media Queries
css-mediaqueries.description: Method of applying styles based on media information. Includes things like page and device dimensions

notes_by_num.1: Does not support nested media queries
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only acknowledging different media rules on page reload

css-mixblendmode.title: Blending of HTML/SVG elements
css-mixblendmode.description: Allows blending between arbitrary SVG and HTML elements

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial in Safari refers to not supporting the `hue`, `saturation`, `color`, and `luminosity` blend modes.

css-motion-paths.title: CSS Motion Path
css-motion-paths.description: Allows elements to be animated along SVG paths or shapes via the `offset-path` property. Originally defined as the `motion-path` property.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag to be enabled

css-namespaces.title: CSS namespaces
css-namespaces.description: Using the `@namespace` at-rule, elements of other namespaces (e.g. SVG) can be targeted using the pipe (`|`) selector.

css-nesting.title: CSS Nesting
css-nesting.description: CSS nesting provides the ability to nest one style rule inside another, with the selector of the child rule relative to the selector of the parent rule. Similar behavior previously required a CSS pre-processor.

links.title: Blog post: CSS Nesting, specificity and you

css-not-sel-list.title: selector list argument of :not()
css-not-sel-list.description: Selectors Level 3 only allowed `:not()` pseudo-class to accept a single simple selector, which the element must not match any of. Thus, `:not(a, .b, [c])` or `:not(a.b[c])` did not work. Selectors Level 4 allows `:not()` to accept a list of selectors. Thus, `:not(a):not(.b):not([c])` can instead be written as `:not(a, .b, [c])` and `:not(a.b[c])` works as intended.

css-nth-child-of.title: selector list argument of :nth-child and :nth-last-child CSS pseudo-classes
css-nth-child-of.description: The newest versions of `:nth-child()` and `:nth-last-child()` accept an optional `of S` clause which filters the children to only those which match the selector list `S`. For example, `:nth-child(1 of .foo)` selects the first child among the children that have the `foo` class (ignoring any non-`foo` children which precede that child). Similar to `:nth-of-type`, but for arbitrary selectors instead of only type selectors.

links.title: Mozilla Bug 854148 - Support for :nth-child(An+B of sel), :nth-last-child(An+B of sel) pseudo-classes
Chromium Issue 304163: Implement :nth-child(an+b of S) and :nth-last-child(an+b of S) pseudo-classes
MS Edge feature request on UserVoice
MS Edge Platform Status: Under Consideration

css-nth-child-of.notes: For support information for just `:nth-child()` see [CSS3 selector support](#feat=css-sel3)

css-opacity.title: CSS3 Opacity
css-opacity.description: Method of setting the transparency level of an element
css-opacity.notes: Transparency for elements in IE8 and older can be achieved using the proprietary "filter" property and does not work well with PNG images using alpha transparency.

css-optional-pseudo.title: :optional CSS pseudo-class
css-optional-pseudo.description: The `:optional` pseudo-class matches form inputs (`<input>`, `<textarea>`, `<select>`) which are not `:required`.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match non-required `<select>`s

css-overflow.title: CSS overflow property
css-overflow.description: Originally a single property for controlling overflowing content in both horizontal & vertical directions, the `overflow` property is now a shorthand for `overflow-x` & `overflow-y`. The latest version of the specification also introduces the `clip` value that blocks programmatic scrolling.

links.title: WebKit bug on support for two values syntax
Edge bug on support for two values syntax
WebKit bug on support for clip value

css-overflow.notes: Effectively all browsers support the CSS 2.1 definition for single-value `overflow` as well as `overflow-x` & `overflow-y` and values `visible`, `hidden`, `scroll` & `auto`

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the two value `overflow` shorthand
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `clip` value

css-overflow-anchor.title: CSS overflow-anchor (Scroll Anchoring)
css-overflow-anchor.description:
Changes in DOM elements above the visible region of a scrolling box can result in the page moving while the user is in the middle of consuming the content.
By default, the value of  `overflow-anchor` is `auto`, it can mitigate this jarring user experience by keeping track of the position of an anchor node and adjusting the scroll offset accordingly

css-overflow-overlay.title: CSS overflow: overlay
css-overflow-overlay.description: The `overlay` value of the `overflow` CSS property is a non-standard value to make scrollbars appear on top of content rather than take up space. This value is deprecated and related functionality being standardized as [the `scrollbar-gutter` property](mdn-css_properties_scrollbar-gutter).

links.title: WebKit change to make "overflow: overlay" a synonym for "overflow: auto"

notes_by_num.1: The `overlay` value is recognized, but behaves the same as "auto".

css-overscroll-behavior.title: CSS overscroll-behavior
css-overscroll-behavior.description: CSS property to control the behavior when the scroll position of a scroll container reaches the edge of the scrollport.

links.title: Google Developers blog post on overflow-behavior

notes_by_num.1: Supports the precursor version of the property: [`-ms-scroll-chaining`](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh772034%28v=vs.85%29.aspx), which works similarly. IE support is limited to Windows 8 & above
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `overscroll-behavior: none;` on the body element to prevent the overscroll glow and rubberbanding effects.
notes_by_num.3: Incorrectly treats `none` as `contain` see [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/overscroll-behavior#Browser_compatibility) and [Edge 18 changelog](https://aka.ms/devguide_edgehtml_18)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in the "Experimental Features" developer menu

css-page-break.title: CSS page-break properties
css-page-break.description: Properties to control the way elements are broken across (printed) pages.

links.title: Latest fragmentation specification (includes column & region breaks)

css-page-break.notes: Not all mobile browsers offer print support; support listed for these is based on browser engine capability.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `page-break-*` alias from the CSS 2.1 specification, but not the `break-*` properties from the latest spec.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `avoid` for `page-break-before` & `page-break-after` (only `page-break-inside`).
notes_by_num.3: Treats the `left` and `right` values like `always`.

css-paged-media.title: CSS Paged Media (@page)
css-paged-media.description: CSS at-rule (`@page`) to define page-specific rules when printing web pages, such as margin per page and page dimensions.
css-paged-media.notes: Currently no browsers appear to support the `marks` & `bleed` properties from the latest version of the specification.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `size` property
notes_by_num.2: Does not appear to have a way to print web pages

css-paint-api.title: CSS Paint API
css-paint-api.description: Allows programmatic generation of images used by CSS

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled using the Develop > Experimental Features menu.

css-placeholder.title: ::placeholder CSS pseudo-element
css-placeholder.description: The ::placeholder pseudo-element represents placeholder text in an input field: text that represents the input and provides a hint to the user on how to fill out the form. For example, a date-input field might have the placeholder text `YYYY-MM-DD` to clarify that numeric dates are to be entered in year-month-day order.

links.title: Mozilla Bug 1069012 - unprefix :placeholder-shown pseudo-class and ::placeholder pseudo-element

css-placeholder.notes:
Partial support refers to using alternate names:
`::-webkit-input-placeholder` for Chrome/Safari/Opera ([Chrome issue #623345](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=623345)) 
`::-ms-input-placeholder` for Edge (also supports webkit prefix)

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 18 and below supported the `:-moz-placeholder` pseudo-class rather than the `::-moz-placeholder` pseudo-element.

css-placeholder-shown.title: :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class
css-placeholder-shown.description: Input elements can sometimes show placeholder text as a hint to the user on what to type in. See, for example, the placeholder attribute in HTML5. The :placeholder-shown pseudo-class matches an input element that is showing such placeholder text.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-placeholder-shown.notes: For support of styling the actual placeholder text itself, see [CSS ::placeholder](https://caniuse.com/#feat=css-placeholder)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to using the non-standard `:-moz-placeholder` name rather than `:placeholder-shown`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to using the non-standard `:-ms-input-placeholder` name rather than `:placeholder-shown`.

css-read-only-write.title: CSS :read-only and :read-write selectors
css-read-only-write.description: :read-only and :read-write pseudo-classes to match elements which are considered user-alterable

links.title: Selectors Level 4 § The Mutability Pseudo-classes: :read-only and :read-write

notes_by_num.1: Supports selector only for input and textarea fields, but not for contenteditable

css-rebeccapurple.title: Rebeccapurple color
css-rebeccapurple.description: The new color added in CSS Color Module Level 4

notes_by_num.1: Only works in IE11 for Windows 10, not older versions of Windows

css-reflections.title: CSS Reflections
css-reflections.description: Method of displaying a reflection of an element

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-reflections.notes: Similar effect can be achieved in Firefox 4+ using the -moz-element() background property

css-regions.title: CSS Regions
css-regions.description: Method of flowing content into multiple elements.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to using an iframe as a content source with the `-ms-flow-into: flow_name;` and `-ms-flow-from: flow_name;` syntax.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the `region-fragment` property.

css-repeating-gradients.title: CSS Repeating Gradients
css-repeating-gradients.description: Method of defining a repeating linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - CSS repeating linear gradient

css-repeating-gradients.notes: Firefox 10+, Chrome 26+ and Opera 11.6+ also support the new "to (side)" syntax.

css-resize.title: CSS resize property
css-resize.description: Method of allowing an element to be resized by the user, with options to limit to a given direction.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
CSS resize none on textarea is bad for UX

notes_by_num.1: Presto-based Opera 12.10+ currently only supports the resize property for textarea elements.

css-revert-value.title: CSS revert value
css-revert-value.description: A CSS keyword value that resets a property's value to the default specified by the browser in its UA stylesheet, as if the webpage had not included any CSS. For example, `display:revert` on a `<div>` would result in `display:block`. This is in contrast to the `initial` value, which is simply defined on a per-property basis, and for `display` would be `inline`.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-rrggbbaa.title: #rrggbbaa hex color notation
css-rrggbbaa.description: The CSS Color Module Level 4 defines new 4 & 8 character hex notation for color to include the opacity level.
css-rrggbbaa.notes: Only supported in Android WebViews in apps that target Android Pie, due to [this issue](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=618472)

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental web platform features" flag.

css-scroll-behavior.title: CSSOM Scroll-behavior
css-scroll-behavior.description: Method of specifying the scrolling behavior for a scrolling box, when scrolling happens due to navigation or CSSOM scrolling APIs.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support everything except of [`Element.scrollIntoView()`](https://caniuse.com/scrollintoview) and [not together with pinch viewport](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=434497).
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Smooth Scrolling' and/or 'Enable experimental web platform features' flag
notes_by_num.3: Supported in Safari via the "CSSOM View Smooth Scrolling" Experimental Features flag.

css-scroll-timeline.title: CSS @scroll-timeline
css-scroll-timeline.description: CSS property that allows animations to be driven by a container's scroll position
